pros: It was a blast working for Apple. Makes for great conversation at parties. I loved helping people with getting their device tech issues resolved. I loved my co-workers and helping in my capacity as a Senior Advisor (Tier 2). The employee discount was helpful - but not awesome. Really good health insurance benefits.
cons: Being a remote (at-home) employee was super lonely. After six years I just burnt out. I repeatedly asked if there was a way the company would support get togethers with nearby advisors so we could connect face to face; but that went nowhere. Eventually I found people nearby and organized an unofficial meeting and had a great time. Networking is so important, but Apple really didn’t support that for people who worked from home. Additionally, the KPI were used as a weapon in ratings. Using numbers and reviews that were out of my control to determine my quarterly and annual review “score” never felt like a way to learn what to improve upon. Constantly asking what I can do to improve in order to get promotions or raises fell on deaf ears, although my Team Manager referred to me as a RockStar. For such a valuable company, they didn’t really pay that well. In my six years I went from $14/hr to just over $20/hr but it was extremely hard fought/won and I was left to myself if I were to have any success. ZERO mentorship offered - little more than words offered by direct management. They don’t really care about you as a person. Oh, and if you want to succeed at Apple I was told by a ‘successful’ employee that you can’t have a life outside of Apple. They’ll say they want you to have work/life balance, but when the rubber hits the road you better be %110 Apple 24/7/365. I hated leaving but I needed to take care of myself and my family.

review_title: Great compared to most retail, but still just a retail job
pros:
-Pay is relatively above average, part time employees get all benefits, employee stock purchase program is a huge plus
-Education assistance, gym membership rebate, doctors, lawyers, therapy, among many other discounted and/or free services (even as just a part time employee! use these!!)
-Not commission based so I don't necessarily feel pressured to upsell products that the customer doesn't need (exception: see cons)
- Get to be surrounded by Apple products all day (as an Apple fan-boy, this was great)
- Great to talk apple products all day with customers, actually try to find the best product variation for them and learning about new and different ways people use their computers and devices
- Discount is great, almost bad due to how much I used it
- A great way to get into Apple Corporate, using "Career Experiences" where you work for corporate for a limited time and possibly get offered a full time job. Apple Retail while going to college is a easy decision to make if you're goal is eventually Apple Corporate.
- Relatively flexible schedule, flexible management
- Having Apple on your resume automatically puts you to the top of the resume list of your next employer (relatively speaking of course, that alone won't do much if you aren't capable of your next opportunity)
- Learn a lot of Apple products to use later in life for yourself and others
cons:
I joined in 2020, so I am not sure how things were before, but I had a lot of people tell me Apple Retail was not as "sales-y" as it has become with its services, especially AppleCare. I understand we have metrics to meet as a public company, but at times, it felt no different than being a commission-based employee with how often they pressured us to sell AppleCare and get Business Intros.
-While Apple is overall a great place to work relatively speaking, it is still just a retail job. Meaning you're co-workers aren't all going to be apple-fanantics who love Apple products and everything about their job. Its going to be like every other job where there are the try-hards, the normal people, and the lazy people. There are going to be bosses who are overly micro-manage-y and some managers who are just great and everything I would want in a manager.
- There are a lot of conflict of interests and policies around technology development and working at other technology jobs. Make sure you have no plans of developing any software while working for Apple unless you plan to let Apple own it. 
- We have a bad habit of letting rude and loud customers get what they want and giving the nice customers who actually deserve an exception a hard time. Really hated appeasing rude and obnoxious customers. Really hated turning down exceptions to customers who asked nicely and were in a situation that warranted an exception. 
- Its easy to sip the Apple Juice, try to remain un-biased and see through the Corporate bs. (But don't become one of the grudegy twitter anon accounts, they're over exaggerating and taking for granted their job at a RETAIL STORE).
